bestBHT.bht: At the end of the section describing Jesus' journey to Jerusalem, the people were very attentive, hanging upon His words. They eagerly stuck by Him, ready to catch every word that dropped from His lips. This scene resonates with the hymn that asks, Did Christ o'er sinners weep? And shall our cheeks be dry? The religious leaders, on the other hand, were at a loss, fearing the people and unable to find an opportunity to seize Him or bring about their wicked plan.

Henry Alford: It is rightly however placed at the end of a chapter, for it forms a close to the long section wherein the last journey to Jerusalem has been described.
Albert Barnes: 'Did Christ o'er sinners weep? And shall our cheeks be dry? Let floods of penitential grief. Burst forth from every eye."
The Son of God in tears. Angels with wonder see! Be thou astonished, O my soul; He shed those tears for thee.
He wept that we might weep; Each sin demands a tear: In heaven alone no sin is found. And there’s no weeping there.
Marvin Vincent: Were very attentive [εξεκρεματο] . Only here in New Testament.
Lit., as Rev., hung upon him. Tynd., stuck by him. ===Luke 20:0
John Gill: They could not find an opportunity of seizing him, nor any advantage against him; they knew not what steps to take, nor how to bring about their wicked design of destroying him.

There were great crowds always about him, that hung upon him, as the word rendered 'attentive' signifies; they heard him with great eagerness and diligence, and were ready to catch every word that dropped from his lips.

The sanhedrim were at a loss what method to make use of to gain their point; and they feared the people, should they seize him publicly, lest they should rise and rescue him, and cause a tumult and disturbance.

bhtAttempts.bht: At the end of a long section describing Jesus' journey to Jerusalem, the people were very attentive to hear him, as if they were hanging upon his every word. The words used to describe this attentiveness convey the image of the people being not only focused on Jesus but also sticking by him. This scene is reminiscent of the Son of God weeping for sinners, as captured in the hymn: Did Christ o'er sinners weep? And shall our cheeks be dry? Let floods of penitential grief burst forth from every eye. It is clear that the crowds had a great eagerness and diligence in listening to Jesus, ready to catch every word that dropped from his lips. The religious leaders, on the other hand, were at a loss and feared the people. They couldn't find an opportunity to seize Jesus or find any advantage against him, leaving them in a state of confusion and uncertainty about how to proceed with their wicked plan to destroy him.

At the end of the section describing Jesus' journey to Jerusalem, the people were very attentive, hanging upon His words. Their great eagerness and diligence in listening to Him is evident as they stuck by Him, ready to catch every word. This scene brings to mind the hymn that asks, Did Christ o'er sinners weep? And shall our cheeks be dry? The religious leaders, in contrast, were at a loss, fearing the people and unable to find an opportunity to seize Him or plot against Him.

The religious leaders, on the other hand, were at a loss, fearing the people and unable to find an opportunity to seize Him or bring about their wicked plan.

At the end of the section describing Jesus' journey to Jerusalem, the people were very attentive, hanging upon Him and sticking by Him. Their eagerness and diligence in listening to Jesus were remarkable, as they were ready to catch every word that dropped from His lips. This intense devotion brings to mind the hymn that asks, Did Christ o'er sinners weep? And shall our cheeks be dry? Meanwhile, the religious leaders struggled to find an opportunity to seize Jesus and feared the people's potential resistance in causing a tumultuous disturbance.
